inference:
The coordinates of the points are: A(0,0), B(6,0), C(3,6), D(6,6), F(0,6), P(3,3).
Since PA = PB = PC, P is the circumcenter of triangle ABC.
The distance from P to each side of the square is equal since PA=PB=PC.
Thus, the point P must be equidistant from all sides of the square.
The coordinates of P are (3,3), which is the center of the square.
Triangle APB is a right triangle with right angle at A.
PA^2 = (3-0)^2 + (3-0)^2 = 9+9 = 18
PB^2 = (3-6)^2 + (3-0)^2 = 9+9 = 18
Since PA^2 = PB^2, triangle APB is an isosceles right triangle.
The length of the base AB is 6.
The length of the sides PA and PB are $\sqrt{18}=3\sqrt{2}$.
The area of triangle APB is (1/2)(6)(3)=9.
Final Answer: $\boxed{9}$
ground_truth:
We first extend line segment $\overline{CP}$ so that it intersects $\overline{AB}$. We'll call this point of intersection point $E$, so $\overline{CE}$ is a perpendicular bisector to segment $\overline{AB}$ and $AE=EB=3$. We also let $x =$ the lengths of segments $\overline{PA}$, $\overline{PB}$, and $\overline{PC}$, so line segment $\overline{PE}$ will have length $6-x$. Now we have that $\triangle AEP$ is a right triangle. Using the Pythagorean Theorem and solving for $x$, we have that:  \begin{align*}
& AE^2+PE^2=PA^2 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & 3^2 + (6-x)^2 = x^2 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & 9 + 36 - 12x + x^2 = x^2 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & 12x = 45 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & x= \frac{15}{4}.
\end{align*}  Thus, $\triangle APB$ has base $6$ and a a height of $6-x=6-\frac{15}{4}=\frac{9}{4}$. It follows that $\triangle APB$ has an area of $\dfrac{1}{2}bh=\dfrac{1}{2} \cdot 6 \cdot \left(\dfrac{9}{4}\right) = \boxed{\dfrac{27}{4}}$ square inches.

PC = $\sqrt{(3-3)^2+(3-6)^2} = \sqrt{0+9} = 3$.  This triangle isn't isosceles, but is right at A. The area of triangle APB is (1/2)(6)(3√2) = 9√2. ground_truth:
We first extend line segment $\overline{CP}$ so that it intersects $\overline{AB}$. We'll call this point of intersection point $E$, so $\overline{CE}$ is a perpendicular bisector to segment $\overline{AB}$ and $AE=EB=3$. We also let $x =$ the lengths of segments $\overline{PA}$, $\overline{PB}$, and $\overline{PC}$, so line segment $\overline{PE}$ will have length $6-x$. Now we have that $\triangle AEP$ is a right triangle. Using the Pythagorean Theorem and solving for $x$, we have that:  \begin{align*}
& AE^2+PE^2=PA^2 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & 3^2 + (6-x)^2 = x^2 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & 9 + 36 - 12x + x^2 = x^2 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & 12x = 45 \\
\Rightarrow \qquad & x= \frac{15}{4}.
\end{align*}  Thus, $\triangle APB$ has base $6$ and a a height of $6-x=6-\frac{15}{4}=\frac{9}{4}$. It follows that $\triangle APB$ has an area of $\dfrac{1}{2}bh=\dfrac{1}{2} \cdot 6 \cdot \left(\dfrac{9}{4}\right) = \boxed{\dfrac{27}{4}}$ square inches.
